trustfund:
TF033628-ECUADOR - EDUCATION FINANCE,TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
Both borrower performance and project
            outcome of the Third Social Development Project are rated
            partially satisfactory. Key lessons drawn from the project
            include: 1) To avoid costly and protracted preparation
            before starting a social fund, it would be advisable to
            decide on the institutional framework, establish and staff
            the implementing agency prior to detailed technical
            preparation. 2) The use of a poverty-targeting strategy
            should be strongly encouraged in all programs targeted to
            benefit poor social groups. 3) Preparation of private
            contractors can help accelerate subproject preparation as
            well as implementation. On the other hand, the benefits of
            rapid implementation must be weighed against the risk of
            conflict of interest that could compromise subproject
            selection. 4) Strengthening and improving grassroots
            organizational capacity to develop subprojects contributes
            to improve all stages of the subprojects cycle. 5) Training
            nongovernmental organizations in subproject promotion and
            development is essential for their full participation in
            social fund projects. 6) Sustainability will be uncertain if
            the beneficiaries are not directly involved in monitoring
            and maintaining their completed subprojects. 7) Continuity
            of technical staff as well as of external technical
            assistance contributed to the establishment and maintenance
            of consistent operating procedures in FISE (Emergency Social
            Investment Fund), despite turnover of managers caused by
            political changes.
